choices.B: From the More actions menu of Materials, filter the selected values.
choices.A: From the More actions menu of Materials, select Group Values, and then select Spelling.
choices.C: From the More actions menu of Materials, select Valid in the Show values section.
choices.D: For the data type of the Material field, select Custom and then select Role1.

questions.question_text:
You connect to a database server by using Tableau Prep The database server has a data role named Role1.

You have the following field in the data.

//IMG//


You need to apply the Role1 data role to the Material field.

Which two actions should you perform? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Tableau Prep compares the values by spelling or spelling and pronunciation and then groups similar values under the standardized value for the data role.
Custom role has been retired from tableau since Feb 2024
i believe it should be first D the A to group values based on spelling to get rid of misspelt words

Selected Answer: BD
Option B is correct because filtering the selected values from the More actions menu allows you to apply the data role Role1 to the Material field by specifying which values are included based on the data role.

Option D is correct because selecting the data type of the Material field as Custom and then choosing Role1 allows you to explicitly assign the Role1 data role to the Material field, ensuring that it is properly controlled and managed according to the specified role's permissions and restrictions.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

choices.A: A diverging color palette that has six stepped colors
choices.C: A diverging color palette that has five stepped colors

discussion.content: given answer is wrong. asking for day field. it must be (Datepart, Day, [Transaction date])

comments.content: sorry given answer is correct. because day field they mention is a field name.

discussion.content:
The answer is correct!
DATENAME('weekday', [Transaction Date])

discussion.content:
1) Open Tableau prep 
2) Create a new column ...
3) Union the sales ...
4) Join the sales ...

It is easy to do with tableau Prep. 1) Open the prep and select common columns (ID, Name, City and Sales). 2) For second dataset(Germany) Concatenate the names 3) Perform union operation 4) Join with population table

comments.content:
This one should not be correct. Correct one should be - 1) Open Tableau prep
2) Create a new column ...
3) Union the sales ...
4) Join the sales ...

discussion.content:
Open Tableau Prep.
Union the sales data of both divisions.
Create a new column to concatenate the name for the Germany division.
Join the sales data and the population data by using City as the join field.
